This aligns with the chosen definition (Option 4: "The perceived 'medicalization' of societies occurs when social issues are increasingly considered and responded to as medical problems.") because it describes the process of social problems being *made* into medical problems, fitting the etymological breakdown of the word. Historically, the term has been used to describe instances where behaviors or conditions previously considered moral failings, social problems, or simply normal variations in human experience are redefined and treated as medical conditions requiring medical intervention. While all three concepts are interconnected, medicalization focuses on the *process* of defining and treating social issues as medical problems, which is distinct from simply defining something as a disease (pathologization) or focusing on the role of biomedical technologies (biomedicalization).
